column2: then "Burken" and finally to "Borken".  Around the year 800 the village was being used by Charles The Great (Charlemagne) as a stopover place on his travels.  In 1226 City rights were granted by Bishop Dietrich II of Isenberg-Limburg.  Fortification of the city with walls and towers was first noted in 1391.

column1: In the last years of the Holy Roman Empire (1803–06) it was the capital of the short-lived principality of Salm.  From 1810 to 1814 it was part of the French Empire.  In 1815 Borken came under the jurisdiction of the Prussian Province of Westphalia.  At the same time it became the seat of government for the newly formed district or county of Borken (Kreis Borken).
